2019高雄設計節開展倒數 2 日！
準備好一窺未來生活設計提案了嗎？

策展人許哲瑜與郭中元將設計觀點回歸日常生活六大領域，設計團隊更是親自走訪高雄，透過在地生活的研究探索，以未來城市為目標提出更多的可能性。

除此之外，展覽現場以輸送帶概念串接六大展區，運送與擴展不同生活面向，串流人．城市．空間的行為關係。

🚏 郵差不再眼花花 區域特色一次奉上
🚕 朋友請上車 移動不設限
🐒 動物園存在的愛恨交織
🚢 港都專屬海上暢遊體驗

馬來西亞人日常早餐是一杯黑咖啡配撒上糖粉的Kaya醬(椰奶果醬)吐司，這樣的吃法對台灣人來說很獨特。來自馬來西亞檳城的
Lefty由日常的一杯咖啡帶出房租統治法下的喬治亞市變遷。

 【下一杯咖啡要到哪裡喝？】
34歲的阿文是道地的檳城人，總習慣在休假日早晨，從「山頂」檳島西南縣一路騎摩托車至「坡底」喬治市，到已傳承三代的南洋咖啡店「廣泰來」吃早餐。一杯oor dao
jia（黑咖啡）配上雞蛋和炭烤吐司，是許多老檳城人的集體記憶。
隨著2000年房租統治法令廢除、2008年列為世界文化遺產，喬治市房租高漲不下，大批觀光人潮更吸引外國財團買走大批老屋，使得在地老行業也步入黃昏，更點出了喬治市居民在觀光產業下的正負影響。

✔ Hello Kab！輕鬆上路，城市移動友善不設限！

 ⓉⓇⒶⓃⓈⓅⓄⓇⓉⒶⓉⒾⓄⓃ 創作團隊｜ADC STUDIO

 城市間的往返移動，相較於一般的公共運輸，
計程車是一種舒適、迅速且方便的服務！

 考慮到每一種「行」的需求，
從計程車的識別系統到硬體設備，都必須深思熟慮。

 ADC STUDIO大刀闊斧賦予高雄計程車新形象，
打造專屬於高雄的計程車系統「HelloKab」，
除了設計車隊標示系統、招呼牌、叫車界面等視覺，
並搭配福斯商旅福祉車Caddy IPC 和 Caravelle IPC兩款車型，
以貼心的無障礙設備，加上活潑親切視覺形象，
期待能為大家帶來全新且更加便利的服務體驗。

 2019高雄設計節「行」單元的展區小彩蛋，
即為一台由藏家提供的1978年出廠裕隆速利301，
是當時計程車運將的愛用車款，
乘載著幾十載的情感，重現於高雄設計節，
以新舊計程車並存來呈現交通的歷史變革與功能進化！

在一般公式化的標識底下，行人對於城市的面貌留下什麼印象呢？

 由廖韡、楊少鈞、黃中星三位設計師參與，各自提出住宅與城市間的關係，希望打破大眾對於標識系統公式化的印象。

#38個行政區區徽未來想像 
38區區徽實驗設計｜廖韡設計工作室 (L / g / s)

 
高雄共有38個行政區，這些聚集不同風土人情，轉換成幾何的虛實抽象元素，就像38個不同的地方品牌，隨時展現著各區特色！38個區徽設計在展場同時搭配動態的呈現，期待透過這樣的設計轉譯，讓這座城市有著不一樣的生命！

 #跟著數字在高雄從一玩到十 
路牌標識系統設計｜楊少鈞

 
一心二聖三多四維...特殊數字路名是高雄的一大特色，設計師實地走訪、城市觀察，將海港、街道巷弄、風俗民情元素濃縮，汲取高雄城市的色彩，用阿拉伯數字巧妙地結合十條路的色彩計畫，製作出新型態的地面牌與燈箱，引領人們悠遊高雄。

 #門牌的微整型 
從門牌潔淨實驗計畫｜黃中星

 
將門牌設計加入高雄的熱情與工業印象，第一步先將畫面淨空，回歸視覺的乾淨享受，再以灰色調融入住宅，降低街景干擾，最後利用切角標示方向，讓識別功能加強，讓民眾找路不再心慌慌。

 愛似聖代，千滋百味，各自體會。
在台南的半年裡我幾乎都躺在房間，與房間裡的物品相處久了，漸漸地發現它們全都很可愛，不同時刻的光線照進來，空氣是那樣溫柔，牆壁的顏色不能再更美了。良久的注視裡，物與我的界線開始模糊，物、我、動物、愛人、他者、宇宙，我的描繪，其實都是自畫像。愛是什麼？每個人都只喜歡自己吧，也只要喜歡自己就夠了。我深愛所有發生，筆與紙的摩擦，每個呼吸，全是我寫給世界的情歌。

承襲著港都海派霸氣的性格，高雄一向是活絡多變的城市，揮別了重工業城市的印象，迎來的是澎湃的藝文設計觀光潮流。在產業經濟、文化、觀光發展之下，軟性設計思維與日常生活對話是不容忽視的城市價值。

 
2019高雄設計節將回歸到日常生活中，改變日常所見的視而不見，開啟更多設計與生活的對話空間，將熟悉的日常事物重新演繹，展現對於未來生活的新提案，發現這座城市的潛在魅力。

#二伯看展覽 《Plus1》 平井里奈 中村幹史 雙人展

 中村幹史與平井里奈是日本年輕一代藝術家，二人共同策劃《Plus1》展覽。
目前他們二人就讀於研究所，中村的專業是繪畫創作，利用粘土和熱塑性樹脂材料，通過塗抹、粘貼等方式，讓材料堆貼若干層，使作品呈現出重量感和質感；
而平井的專業是陶藝創作，透過在陶土表面雕刻不同的紋樣來製作作品。
此次展覽所展出的作品是他們結合此前創作活動的經驗，並在那基礎上創作出的新作品。

 作品名稱：停 看 聽 Stop, Look and Listen
作者：阿曼Arman

 American artist Arman was one of the few artists written into the history of
contemporary Western art during his lifetime. The most famous art style he used
involved giving daily ready-made objects new looks and meanings by repetition,
stacking, cutting, and rearrangement to create extreme Assemblage art. Located
in the outdoor plaza of TRA Xinzuoying Station, “Stop, Look and Listen” is the
only public art Arman created in Taiwan. He stacked obsolete level crossing
signs together to demonstrate the accumulation of human life and emotions,
showing how art can be used to preserve objects that have lost function and
identity, and given new meanings and values.

 Sound Tree, a piece created by South Korean steel and iron artist Sung
Dong-hun, combines nature and culture. Sung employs exceptional metalwork
presentation techniques to transform scrap metal collected from Kaohsiung’s
local steel and iron factories into a lofty tree. The uneven surfaces of steel
plates are transformed into tree bark, whereas iron nets and bars are wrought
into branches and leaves. The tree tops are decorated with bells that ring
pleasantly in the breeze, making the artwork “one with sound.” This piece
highlights the characteristics of steel and iron materials that resonate with
Kaohsiung’s industrial past. Sung makes use of natural wind effects in his work
to create experiences that connect viewers and art in a natural environment.

surroundings.

 作品名稱：巨人的積木 Giant 's building blocks
作者：吳寬瀛 Kuan-ying Wu
創作年份：2017
材質規格：貨櫃 / 長12.5m x寬12.5m x高10m
設置地點：駁二藝術特區

 At the intersection of the light rail and Dayong St. is “Giant’s Building
Blocks”, a large installation made of red containers, and The Pier-2 Art
Center’s new landmark.
Its creator Wu Kuan-ying is an artist skilled in building blocks and geometric
structure. Wu stated that “sculpting and clay modeling involve subtraction and
addition, respectively, whereas art creation using building blocks involves
addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division.” This artwork, with only
three supports, reveals how its creator ingeniously played with structural
combinations.
Old containers were remodeled, polished, and rebuilt similar to a kid playing
with building blocks, creating a sense of experimentation and novelty. The world
becomes the artist’s playground and creativity.

 The Wei-Wu Mi-Mi Street Art Village is the largest painted art village in

the Wallriors Street Art Festival since 2016, a festival that invites domestic

immersive theater events, in which guided tours featuring puzzle-solving
elements, actors, and sounds are used to guide visitors through Wei-Wu Mi-Mi

 The KUBIC Container Park is the first experimental venue in southern Taiwan and
serves as a platform of exchange for local innovative enterprises following
urban transformation in the Asia New Bay Area.
Kaohsiung Shui Shui is a landscape installation in the container park designed
by the winners of the 2019 Golden Pin Design Award and the 2019 12th Taiwan
Interior Design Award. They incorporated the coastline of Kaohsiung harbor into
two curved concrete walls (measuring 18 and 36 meters long), where the walls
resemble hills rising from the ground. Additionally, mist is sprayed from the
walls to symbolize the mountains and sea of our industrial city.
The use of mist in here creates a dialogue with the surrounding environment in
both real and imaginary form, with the creators hoping that it facilitates the
creation of a “Shui Shui (meaning “beautiful” in Taiwanese)” future for
Kaohsiung and its harbor.

Message of Peace, Multidimensional Visual Communication 9 X 6 X 18
作者：亞科夫．亞剛 Yaacov Agam
創作年份：2009
材質尺寸：氟碳烤漆、鋼筋水泥 / 108 × 95.53 × 1082cm

 Standing tall in the National Stadium outdoor square is Message of Peace,
Multidimensional Visual Communication 9 X 6 X 18, a piece comprising of nine
colorful hexagonal pillars designed by world-renowned Israeli artist Yaacov
Agam. 
With nine columns, six sides, and 18 grids, viewers must walk around to see the
artwork and create varying multi-dimensional visual changes. Agam once said that
many works of art are flat and “frozen;” he is the first artist to incorporate
the element of “time” in art. In Hebrew, the concept of present tense does not
exist; instead, the language forms an endless flow of time and space. This
religious philosophy deeply influences Agam’s creative thinking, inspiring him
to create an art piece that requires viewers to move continuously and produce
art that embodies both the elements of movement and time.

 Outside the National Stadium is a “car” that seems to be covered with a sports
track. However, this is not an actual car but rather a public art called “Let’s
go!” developed by German art group Inges Idee.
Inges Idee is exceptionally gifted at combining spatial environment, social and
human culture, and urban characteristics to present them in a whimsical and
humorous manner. Brightly colored illustrations are utilized to transform the
function-oriented environment into an engaging setting. Inges Idee impeccably
integrates the architectural style and spirit of the National Stadium into the
piece by incorporating various aspects of the stadium (e.g., linear patterns,

exemplify an artist spirit that also complements the building.

有如孕育生命的子宮與魯凱族精神標誌的百合花，

 作品名稱：心靈懸掛的地方Where Souls are Hung
作者：安聖惠 Eleng Luluan
創作年份：2009
材質尺寸：鋼板塑形、晶土色片拼貼、水泥、鋼筋 / 500x600cm
設置地點：高雄市原住民故事館(高雄市前鎮區翠亨北路390號)

 Rukai artist Eleng Luluan is an expert in creating mixed media sculpture and
environment-based art installations. Her works often tackle the issues of women
and environments that exemplify indigenous people’s pursuit of cultural
identity. Where Souls are Hung, exhibited in the Kaohsiung Indigenous Hub, is
rich in creativity and demonstrates indigenous lifestyles.
Before the public cemetery policy was introduced during Japanese Rule, the Rukai
traditionally buried their deceased indoors, giving birth to the Rukai word
“Takelandhane Ki abake” (home/house). This word means “where souls are hung.”
Eleng transformed this notion of home/house into a lily-like streamlined design,
the spiritual symbol of the Rukai people, symbolizing a uterus giving birth to
life. Dew on the tip of a flower petal is tied closely to spiritual concepts
that indicate cultural change and transmission.

創作年份：2009
材質：鋼、鐵 / 300×300×210cm
設置地點：駁二藝術特區

 For this piece, artist Liu Po-chun used metal materials and industrial
technology to symbolize the evolution of human labor and time, smelting scrap
metal to form beautiful lines that create a “gentle” piece of art featuring
humanistic characteristics that contrast the hard material with soft forms. This
urges us to reflect on the social environment and material evolution.
This work was created based on the profile silhouettes of five people, with
rough and cold steel bars bent to form the shapes of foreheads, eyes, noses, and
lips to elicit a sense of familiarity from the viewer. Liu utilizes these large
silhouettes to resonate with his audience and invite them to search for the
beautiful faces that they wish to embody.
Giving scrap metal new life reveals an industrial overproduction, urging us to
slow down and rediscover the relationship and warmth in human interaction as
well as the connectivity between human and natural environments.

 作品名稱：築夢時代 The Age of Dreams
作者：尤瑪．達陸 Yuma Taru
創作年份：2009
材質尺寸：苧麻、羊毛、瓊麻、石材/ 600×220 cm
設置地點：高雄捷運凱旋站

 Found in the Kaisyuan Metro Station, The Age of Dreams was created by Yuma
Taru, an Atayal artist who received the honorary title of “important preserver
of traditional art.” The piece, made from ramie and hand-dyed wool yarn (mediums
rarely used in public art), reveal the labor and “natural colors” in indigenous
tribes via delicate interweaving techniques.
The fiber materials showcase a contrast between lines and texture as well as
unique textural strength. Hidden in simple artwork are natural conditions and
social customs of Yuma’s homeland as well as a place of physical and mental
comfort for those who travel to cities to pursue their dreams.

 The Presence of Guan Yu was the second piece created by South Korean artist
Sung Dong-hun (after Sound Tree) for the Kaohsiung International Steel & Iron
Sculpture Festival, in which he polished naturally formed furnace slag into a
chair. Sitting on the chair is a steel and iron-wrought Guan Yu righteously
gripping a Green Dragon Crescent Blade. The core concept of art creation is to
explore one’s temporal presence. Sung believes that staying true to the present
is another “representation” of righteousness, a virtue synonymous with the lore
of Guan Yu that Sung conveys through new mediums.
Beside The Presence of Guan Yu is an empty chair, an object that often appears
in homes and offices. This empty chair is Sung’s invitation for bypasses to sit
and chat with Guan Yu about their presents.

 作品名稱：鎮音獸傳奇 Legend of Zhen Yin Shou
作者：李億勳Yi-Hsun Lee
創作年份：2007
材質尺寸：RC水泥、磁磚 / 140x60x55cm

 Influenced by airplanes’ loud noises, artist Lee Yi-hsun created “Legend of
Zhen Yin Shou” situated in Ming Yi Elementary School based on the idea of
“yāshèngwù”. 
Yāshèngwù is an object used by traditional Chinese society to ward off evil
spirits. In this artwork, round and whimsically auspicious zhen yin shou with
whale-ish heads, lizard-ish eyes, cat-ish ears, a dolphin-ish body, a fishy
back, bird-like wings, and a foxlike tail are introduced. The zhen yin shou love
to play with children, are fascinated by wonderful music and children’s
laughter, and hate noises. They will repel objects that create noise until the
sounds disappear.
The school introduces the aforementioned fable into its curriculum and
incorporates mosaic art into its aesthetic education, developing students’ art
competence that fulfill the functions and “tasks” of public art.

作者：林建佑、林韋佑、蘇家賢、黃小明Chien-Yo Lin, Wei-Yu Lin, Chia-Hsien Su, Xiao-Ming Haung
創作年份：2014
材質尺寸：金屬、烤漆、玻璃纖維強化塑膠、混凝土、發光二極體 / 1395×760×145 cm
設置地點：高雄市立五福國民中學

 Founded in 1967, the Wufu Junior High School was built during the modernism
era. As a result, many of its facades contain reliefs with geometric patterns
that were common at the time. The school boasts many large walls with
sculptures, some of which made by local Kaohsiung artist Song Shih-hsiung.
Accordingly, a team of artists worked together to restore some of the
aforementioned walls and turn them into public art. One of said public art is
Happily Go.
In this artwork, anthropomorphic lamps were used to represent diligent students,
and a book page’s corner was turned to reveal facades with reliefs, transforming
2D reliefs into 3D reliefs that symbolize enrolled or graduating students
starting a new chapter in their lives. The students hop on a flying boat to
pursue their dreams and paint their lives with bright colors.
This public art successfully illustrates the deep connection between time and
space, and is a continuation of the campus’ past.

 作品名稱：傳承Inheritance
作者：尼誕‧達給伐歷Nitjan Takivalit
創作年份：2009
材質規格：不鏽鋼 / 高500cm、300cm
設置地點：高雄市原住民故事館(高雄市前鎮區翠亨北路390號)

 Paiwan artist Nitjan Takivalit created most of his artworks based on personal
life experience. Such experience comes from his surroundings and indigenous
tribal culture. Accordingly, his artworks depict a strong sense of cultural
transmission and tribal life. Located by the Kaohsiung Indigenous Hub,
Inheritance features a five-meter-tall adult and a three-meter-tall child statue
that present a solemn and respectful appearance. The artwork is based on
Nitjan’s personal tribal experience; when senior tribal members become old,
weak, and unable to work or hunt, they will put on formal attire and pass their
life experience, skills, wisdom, and spirit to the younger generation (usually
in their grandchildren’s generation). This piece is placed beside the Kaohsiung
Indigenous Hub to advocate the passage of experience.
